26707ba3b6941978ee5130fb658c84f4.title: Doing the Right Thing > Doing Things Right
26707ba3b6941978ee5130fb658c84f4.description: It's easy to find yourself caught in the trap of just GSD (getting shit done) and not stepping back to be thoughtful about whether you'd benefit from doing fewer things but doing those things truly well.

paragraphs.name: 5f0a
paragraphs.text: Hopefully somebody’s asking whether the forest should be cleared in the first place. Increasingly, not asking and answering questions at that level is what’s going to get us all into trouble. Whether it’s Zuckerberg failing to ask and adequately answer questions on news and democracy (yes, I read the manifesto) or the CEO of some defense-tech company…

paragraphs.text: Awesome post! I believe this is a direct parallel to smart ‘product strategy and thinking’ as well….simply releasing a lot of features and updates might be ‘efficient’ and feel like ‘movement’, but it’s also a vanity metric. Your post applies this logic to the entire company, which I completely agree with. ‘Your product isn’t the product, the company…

paragraphs.name: b89b
paragraphs.text: So critical for small companies. Start with the result you wish to achieve and manage to it. Allows you to maintain focus and remove distractions.
Love the top-down thinking, bottom up planning concept. It makes so much sense.

9c59d8f6f46.title: Love the top-down thinking, bottom up planning concept. It makes so much sense.

paragraphs.name: e2c9
paragraphs.text: Nice concise blog. I agree in setting clear guidelines and directions to focus on efficient results that do not hinder growth. I like, “The reality is that you might be better off doing less activity but doing “the right” activities really well.” Keeping both ears open to new ideas from everyone in the group, clients & customers is one simple way to…

paragraphs.text: Effectiveness over efficiency is another way to put it.

bd6e67e107c0.title: Effectiveness over efficiency is another way to put it.

paragraphs.text: Gold 📝👂

paragraphs.name: d49c
paragraphs.text: Great post. And I think it applies to VCs as well. As an investor one can go on running around “sourcing” deals, attending events, grabbing coffees, and even blogging, but in the end it might not translate well into actual results. Its always useful to use a top down approach and figure out your tactics from your strategy. Tactics without a coherent strategy almost always turn out to be useless.

paragraphs.name: 9ec5
paragraphs.text: Agree. It is difficult because we startupper have always really few time, but we must reserve some time each week to understand if we’re heading the right direction or we’re doing only useless actions. It’s hard and I admit that most of weeks I don’t do this… thanks for sharing this article

97f98e5df342.name: Both Sides of the Table

paragraphs.text: It’s the parable of the tree-chopping team that is so focused on efficiency of how fast it can fell a tree that it doesn’t bother to make sure it is clearing the forest in the right direction when one person actually stops the constant cutting to climb a tree and make sure they’re cutting in the right direction. On the surface this person is losing efficiency but in the long-run the gains for direction setting are huge.
paragraphs.name: 1b30
000a
paragraphs.text: So my corollary has always been “doing the right things is more important than doing things right.” Sounds simple but in practice I promise you most organization fall into the latter trap.

The reality is that you might be better off doing less activity but doing “the right” activities really well. To do the right activities you need to start with a top down assessment with what you’re trying to achieve in your organization.
paragraphs.name: ec2d
ec2d
paragraphs.text: The reality is that you might be better off doing less activity but doing “the right” activities really well. To do the right activities you need to start with a top down assessment with what you’re trying to achieve in your organization.

You have a marketing department with three people. They’re tasked with doing … marketing. So they create a task list of all the marketing activities an organization can do: press releases, web site updates, customer case studies, blog posts, daily Tweets, Facebook fan page, attending conferences, etc. You get a lot of traffic — not always results. If you aren’t careful every PR team will measure inches over impact. Vanity metrics will make you feel good about site traffic of SEO over conversion rate or purchases of your product will get more attention than retention. Efficiency can be an addictive drug.
paragraphs.name: 86aa
